title: 417-I-59-ha-ho
body:
I don't like paying more for something when I know I can find it elsewhere for much less. You dig? That's why I love Froogle. However, when it comes to getting a phone for the theater, I don't have much of a choice. It's SBC or nothing. I could use a VoIP service, like Vonage, but they're still too new for my liking. Plus, Vonage can't be used for data lines (i.e. credit card transactions). Let me break it down for you again... you know I only say it ’cause I’m truly genuine... don’t be a hard rock when you really are a gem... sorry. I don't know what came over me just then.

MOXIE LINES
Line 1 - Business line
Line 2 - Movie line
Line 3 - Credit card line

According to SBC, I have two choices for my first line. I can pay $48.95 for a line that includes everything (long distance, call forwarding, caller ID, and a whole bunch of other stuff we don't need). After that, each additional line is $39.99... DAAAAAMN, GINA! That's a lot of money. Not to mention the additional $29.99 we have to pay for DSL, which, regardless of what anyone else thinks, is ESSENTIAL. So, I ask the SBC sales lady, "what's the absolute lowest I can get a line for. I don't need long distance or call forwarding or anything like that. Just a local line. Period." The answer: $34.25! So there it is, my two choices: $160 for a line with everything or $135 for a bare-bones set-up.

You'we in big twouble, mistew.

I just don't understand it. I pay $17.95 for our home phone. It doesn't do anything special other than work when I pick it up... 72% of the time. So why can't I get a business line for the same price? According to a friend of mine who works for SBC - we'll call him Deep Throat - there's absolutely no difference between a residential line and a business one... other than the "perceived notion" that the business line will have a higher call volume than the one wired into your kitchen. I don't know about that, because I can remember my sister talking on the phone for a good eight to ten hours back when she was in junior high.

I'm telling you, SBC is bending me over and delivering the biggest slushy-gushy hug of all TIME! But what else can I do? I can't comparison shop with PacBell for a better deal. Argh! I just have to lay here and take it... right in the phone hole! I'm so disgusted, I don't know what else to say... so I'm going to sing a song:

comments.author: Aaron Scott
comments.body:
For some reason, my mom doesn't appreciate that I use the most basic telephone service, too. No caller ID, no call waiting, no long distance. On top of that, my cell phone is seven years old and the battery lasts for about three and a half minutes. So, Camdenton doesn't hear from me very often.

But hell, it works for me!

comments.author: Steve Kirks
comments.body:
Dan:

My day job is an engineer for NuVox Communications, a company that sells phone service and internet access to businesses. The SBC prices you were quoted do not include their surcharges--extra fees they are allowed to charge to "recover costs".

A $34.25 line will likely have another $7 worth of surcharges, then taxes, too.

Call me at 877-4792 and I'll walk you through it. Maybe we can pick you a couple of cool numbers to have...

I used to work for MCI selling their local phone service (yes I was an annoying telemarketer for about four months). They have a business plan with high speed internet too. Here's some stuff I found on their website:

For $59.99 a month you can get unlimited nationwide calling and all the features and add high speed internet for $50 and up to 14 additional phone lines for addtional costs (which I couldn't find the prices online for). You might be looking at a slightly cheaper price with them.

Just something to look into.

comments.author: ron
comments.body:
you should get Mediacom cable, then get Vonage, and process your debit/credit card purchases through a browser-based point of sale system. I run a business in town here and have been using the Mediacom/Vonage combo for phone/highspeed Internet access for more than a year now and the service hasn't hiccupped once. BofA handles my merchant account, and has a great browser-based POS system. I gave up SBC because they pissed me off about the rates too, and didn't care when I threatened to switch to another carrier. Then I realized that there weren't any others, so I gambled on Vonage. It's worked like a champ ever since.
PS - No "thank you" for pointing out the 417 article last week?

comments.author: open up and say AH
comments.body: Let's face it, the communications industry is handcuffed by the government.  On every one of your phone/DSL/cell bills, you will see a high number of taxes and fees just to recoup the fees charged by the government.  These are the costs that drive the bill up.  However, if you want good quality service, SBC can provide that.  How many times have you picked up your landline and not had a dialtone?  DSL is still in its birth phase, it has a while to maturity so there are some outage issues still.  Cell phones are the same way.  Until the FCC gets their game in order, prices will be high for communications.  VOIP is still in its infancy, and you are definitely going to need 911 service in case of an emergency at your theater.  Don't hesitate to call if you need help setting things up, we have discussed different options in the past.  Keep hope alive, hope is on the horizon with all of the new technologies coming our way.

comments.author: ron
comments.body: Vonage has 911 service.  And it works.  Forget about DSL.  You need SBC to provide that, so it's kind of pointless to think about using DSL as a basis for Vonage, isn't it?  You need CABLE Internet service, not DSL.  DSL is slow, and since it's provided by SBC, it defeats the purpose of switching to Vonage.  Vonage is reliable (more dial tone reliability thatn SBC) and a heck of a lot less expensive than even the basic SBC service.  And you get a toll-free number.  And all your long distance (USA and Canad) is included in the basic fee. We make a lot of calls to Australia, Japan, and other Asian countries, and the rates are three to four cents per minute.  You can't beat that with a popcorn-mixing stick, and the service is so clear.

comments.author: ron
comments.body: I meant "Canada," not "Canad." And don't let those SBC guys tewll you that VOIP is still in a "birthing phase." They're trying to get you to hold off until SBC has a VOIP service to provide.  Even SBC's land line services can't match the services included with Vonage's basic service.  3-way calling, conference calling, voicemail that works, and automatically sends the message to your email so you can archive the .wav voicemail message files instead of clogging up your voicemail, 911 service, call forwarding to your cell phone, and then back to your voicemail if you don't answer your cell phone, caller ID, call waiting, etc., etc.  AND... you can use your regular phones (even cordless ones) and you can use all of the phoine jacks in your office or home.
